publicationStmt.p: This digital edition is part of Lorenzo Ferroni's doctoral dissertation and has been published on the website of the DAL (Digital Alexanderlied) Project (Unversity of Verona, PI: Prof. Maria Adele Cipolla). Please contact Lorenzo Ferroni (lorenzo.ferroni@univr.it) for more info.

msItem.note: with interpolations from the Sächsische Weltchronik (fols. 7r-8r) and Jans von Wien's Weltchronik (fols. 8v-10v).

with Basler Zusätze which must have been integrated in the text after 1396. This terminus post quem can be inferred from what is said about the Black Death epidemic of 1346: "und hat es denocht in | den l ioren niut volgangen" (fol. 177ra, ll. 9-10).

with various additions by later hands and interpolations from Königshofen's Chronik, the Kolmarer Chronik, the Notae historicae Argentinenses, the Rötteler Chronik, and the Konstanzer Jahrbücher. For more information, see the VisColl visualization of the manuscript.

support.p: Dimensions of the folios: Height: 290mm. Width: 210mm.
Dimensions of the written area: Height: 200-240mm. Width: 150-170mm.

supportDesc.collation: Collation: The main book, which originally had 228 folios, and two booklets (the first of 14, the second of 8 folios) that were added later. However, the total number of leaves nowadays is not 250, as it should be, but 231. In fact, 19 leaves have been removed or cut off during the life of the manuscript. Of the main book, 10 folios are missing: one between fols. 208 and 209, four between fols. 209 and 210 (which were probably already missing before 1460, when that section was being written, as the content of fol. 210r is the direct continuation of what is written on fol. 209v), and 5 (which were cut out after 1474) between fols. 217 and 218. The other 9 missing leaves belonged to the first added booklet and were positioned between fols. 223 and 224. A possible collation formula (automatically generated by VisColl) is: 1(12), 2(12), 3(12), 4(12), 5(12), 6(12), 7(12), 8(12), 9(12), 10(12), 11(12), 12(12), 13(12), 14(12), 15(12), 16(12), 17(12), 18(12, -5, -7, -8, -9, -10), 19(12, -7, -8, -9, -10, -11), 20(14, -6, -7, -8, -9, -10, -11, -12, -13, -14), 21(8). Here is a visualization of the manuscript's quire structure realized via VisColl: https://vceditor.library.upenn.edu/project/63bd7ad516d2310001b4cf23/viewOnly.
supportDesc.condition: Condition: The manuscript is currently under restoration, as the iron-gall ink is piercing the paper and is causing damage to the manuscript.

layout.p:
Layout:
1r-179r: two-column layout, with each column containing between 22 and 25 lines of text.
179v-231v: one-column layout, with each page containing between 32 to 43 lines of text.

handDesc.handNote: The first part of the book (Sächsische Weltchronik) was written by unknown hand (H1). It can be described as a younger Gothic cursive, a script which was approximatively used from the last two decades of the 14th century to the third decade of the 15th. This timeframe coincides with the chronological span between addition of the Basler Zusätze to the Sächsische Weltchronik and Appenwiler’s integrations.

Erhard von Appenwiler (H2) wrote nearly all of the second part of the main book of the Basler Handschrift, namely the annals from the Pairis Abbey, his Chronik, various notes in Latin, the scattered sections coming from the composite manuscript of Jakob Twinger von Königshofen’s Chronik, the notes on king Frederick’s coronation, the list of nobles who fell in Sempach, and the Latin exempla. Appenwiler also wrote the second booklet, which begins with a prayer parody on fol. 224r, though the remaining leaves were later filled with historical notes on the Basel war of 1444-1446. Finally, Appenwiler also adds various marginalia (mainly headers) throughout the whole SW section, also filling blank spaces with historical notes.

After Appenwiler’s death in 1472, part of his possessions was inherited by a not-more-precisely-identifiable Magister Nicolai, who may have also acquired the book and might have started writing on it, though no evidence supports this hypothesis. We know only that an anonymous writer (H3) began a continuation of the chronicle on fol. 217r, leaving a blank space on fol. 216v, which later used to record historical events from the year 1473. This unidentified hand stopped writing around that time, possibly because the book was given to another person or because the owner died.

Heinrich Sinner (H4) mainly wrote the whole first booklet (fols. 219r-223v), which contains the Rötteler Chronik, and is very likely the one who bound this booklet (and probably also the second one) to the main codex. On fol. 233v, the Rötteler Chronik breaks off in the middle of a sentence, suggesting that at least the first of the nine missing folios also contained sections from the same work. Sinner added an excerpt from this chronicle on fol. 186r and wrote additional notes on blank spaces throughout the manuscript, including the section on year 1474 on fol. 216v alongside the text written by H3. He also may have written the now illegible text on the blacked-out folio 217v and what was written in the five subsequent cut-out leaves.

Hans Wiler (H5) is the next person who actively uses the codex, adding various notes on it. These additions are scattered throughout the manuscript (in the blank spaces of the SW section, alongside Appenwiler’s marginalia, and in other areas of Appenwiler’s Chronik) and consist of unconnected historical annotations up to 1540. Additional annotations by Wiler appear on the inner margins of the stubbed pages following fol. 223.

The codex was also used by another person, the so-called Meister Berlinger (H6), who added further notes on fols. 218r and 226r. Meister Berlinger was a scribe who worked for Adelberg Meyer, mayor of the city of Basel, who commissioned him the redaction of a manuscript completed in 1545 (Basel, Universitätsbibliothek, Cod. H IV 27) which also contains, among other historiographical works, excerpts from Appenwiler’s Chronik.

From the 16th-17th century, the manuscript was owned by the university, as evidenced by two stamps found on fols. 1r and 231v, as well as the 17th-century note "Academis | Basiliensis | origo" written by the librarian Konrad Pfister (H7) in the margin of fol. 201v. The codex has been housed at the Basel university library since around 1830.

origin.p: Written in Basel between 1396 and 1439, with additions until 1474.

provenance.p: Entered in Erhard of Appenwiler's possession around 1439.
Inherited by another person (maybe Magister Nicolai) after Appenwiler's death in 1472.
Eneterd in Heinrich Sinner's possession around 1474.

Entered in possession of the Zschekenbürlin family after Sinner's death. This is evidenced by a sentence on the inside of the parchment cover: "Hicce liber est Elsbet Scheckenbuerlin", identifying Sinner’s great-granddaughter. The codex was also used by Elsbeth's husband, Hans Wiler.
Probably entered in Adelberg Meyer zum Pfeil's possession, as witnessed by the notes of Meister Berlinger, who worked for him.

acquisition.p: From the 16th-17th century, the manuscript was owned by the university, as evidenced by two stamps found on fols. 1r and 231v, as well as the 17th-century note "Academis | Basiliensis | origo" written by the librarian Konrad Pfister in the margin of fol. 201v. The codex has been housed at the Basel university library since around 1830.
